physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. It is typed on Amy Lowell’s stationary, with the engraved heading "Miss A. Lowell, Heath Street, Brookline, Mass." The words "John Gould" are written in pencil across the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am very glad you have landed on these shores and I hope to see you before long. I am going on to New York next Monday to attend to some business and I want you to dine with me on Tuesday evening at the Hotel St. Regis, Fifth Avenue, and we can have a good old-fashioned talk about everything in general and the state of things in America in particular.

Now I have a little blow for you and a little of what I hope is going to be good news. In the first place Mr. Mosher has returned your book to me with a very kind note saying that he has given up the publication of any new poetry on his own hook and will only publish for authors at their own expense. They tell me he is getting very tired and is not well. He is also giving up the "Bibelot," a magazine which he has run for twenty years, so I think his remarks are bona fide. I will tell you all my tentative efforts with your book when I see you. I could not bear to write to you of a complete break-down of your hopes for its publication, but I think I have landed it with a publisher at last and with a most excellent publisher, namely Messrs. Houghton Mifflin & Company. Mr. Greenslet is extremely enthusiastic over it and it is in his hands now, and although I have not been told definitely that they have accepted it, still from what he says I think that is practically the case. As soon as he lets me know definitely I will drop you a line.

I am having a hard time with the publication of our anthology over here. The publishers shy away from Hueffer’s "Heaven" like a plague and what I am going to succeed in doing I cannot imagine, however I guess it will all come out right in the end.

Let me know your address in New York and let me be sure to see you on Tuesday night as I am going home on Wednesday. I sent you a copy of my book. Did you ever get it, I wonder? If not I will bring one to New York with me because I want you to have it from me.
